summary: The Weight of Silence
title: The Weight of Silence
body:
My first ever semi-fan fic, Editor!Hardy AU

Rating: Mature, for deep angst and sexual content

Wordcount: 6800

Warnings: mentions of abuse, shades of dubcon (but it’s very consensual)

I was part of other fandoms as a teenager, and been disenchanted, so I didn’t do it in adulthood. In my 20′s, I was one of those bitches who barely watched television, didn’t read comic books or stan actors/actresses, and only watched sometimes irritating, ridiculous indie films for the “brilliant photography”. Artsy Hipster trash.

I wrote for another popular blog - OC erotica - but I was miserable and uninspired. I was beyond writing just hanky-panky. I wanted to write more than porn, but at the time, I felt it was all I was good at. I didn’t feel I had the focus and the creativity to breathe life into a character and give them a compelling story. I subscribed to Netflix out of boredom. I adored Olivia Colman. I avoided Broadchurch for months because I don’t like police procedurals (ha! joke’s on me) but I couldn’t resist more Olivia. Enter Hardy. I was bested. I wrote this, left it alone in shame since I DON’T DO FAN FICTION WTF EWW IT’S SO EMBARRASSING UGH -

[I’m really putting myself out there. Please forgive my blindness.]

But I had to come back to it a few months later. I had to finish it. For years and years, all this *waving at the beautiful madness* went over my head. Then, I saw David. Oop! It had to happen sometime. Here I am.

And here it is.

Her heart hammered in her ears.

She yelled. She didn’t mean to yell. It was his eyes, so extraordinarily lovely - the very heart of autumn - were impassive, even as she spilled over in his shitty cabinet of a kitchen, trembling and hyperventilating with emotion. He remained hunched over, silent.

She flexed her hand. Her wrist was numb. She banged it on his counter, making his cups tinkle. She cursed loud enough to make his neighbors stare as she ran back to her car.

The echo of what she said filled her with an exhilarating dread. He knew now. She laid everything bare. In her passion she hadn’t only spoken her feelings for him, but made no secret of the way she felt about the way he lived his life.

Drama made her ill. She shivered, although sweat beaded her brow. She licked her lip and tasted salt. She couldn’t drive like this. She grabbed her bag on the passenger seat, and for some reason, the act finally broke her.

Her breathless, strangled groans strengthened quickly to howls. She squeezed her bag in her hands, wrung the empty flaccid thing. Her tears were plentiful and fast, and soon the leather was streaked with saltwater. She looked back at the empty passenger seat and her body stiffened. She couldn’t do it a second longer. Wait. Endure.

She opened the door to run.

“Oof!” She nearly knocked him over.

She wiped her eyes violently. “What are you doing?!” She slammed the door and started down the entrance of his courtyard. The sodium lights made his brown hair flash auburn.

“Stop.” She kept walking. Her cheeks stung. “You can’t go anywhere in that condition. Come inside. I’ll make you a cup of tea.” 

She stopped walking, but didn’t turn around.

“Come on,” he said. She heard the gravel under his heels, the slight hitch a back injury has caused.

She looked down at her waterlogged bag, then at the road. She followed him back to his cottage. He closed the door behind her, his delicate hands overly precious on the deadlock. She had wanted, and wondered at his hands.

Now he knew.

He walked to the kitchen, ducking his head on the glass fixture that hung too low. It swung softly as he made her favorite. He had made it many times - it was a thoughtless exercise. She ached, but still drank in his silence. The vertical lines between his eyes were deep. His hands were steady, pouring and stirring. The thought of his pity, of a kindness rendered to a friend in pain, made her mouth fill with saliva. She hiccuped.

He set the cup down in front of her. “Drink.” He adjusted his worn tie. His jaw clenched, but his eyes were soft. She took the cup in her hand, warm ceramic, rounded and comfortable. There was chip on the lip. She rubbed her bottom lip against it.

“My neighbor. He said you were crying in your car.”

She swallowed too deeply, and hissed as it burned down her throat.

“Really loudly.” His eyes made her hand tremble. She put the cup down. Rolled her sore eyes.

“I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to cause a disturbance.” She meant it. Now that she was empty of passion, her outburst seemed ridiculous. She stood up. “Thank you. I…um…think I’m okay to drive now.” She took quick strides to the door. “I’m sorry for everything I said it was ridiculous display I’ve been under a lot of stress lately please forget I ever did it-” Her words tumbled together. She hit the door running, nearly tore the knob off.

“I don’t want to forget.” It was barely louder than breath.

She stopped cold, turned her head to look at him. He stood by his table, lips parted, with expectant eyes. She was punch drunk.

“Come inside.” He pointed to his sofa. “Please.”

She was dangerously close to tears again. She wanted to run into his arms, hug him, begin memorizing his limbs. Instead, she sat by him. He was silent for a full minute, looking down at his tented fingers. She looked at his hands too, empty, sifting the light. She waited. She could exist there forever, in that silence. It crackled.

“Trouble,” he said.

“Hmm?” He woke her from her day dream.

“The first time I saw you. You were none too kind,” he said.

“We met at an awkward time.”

“No, you thought I was here to micromanage you.”

“I did. You did, for a while.”

“I’m sorry.”

“Trouble. Why?” she said.

“You. It was what I thought the first time I saw you.” He smiled down at his hands. “You’re right, though. We did meet at an awkward time.”

She had pieced together the two sentence story in the course of their year working together.

His wife cheated, then left. He was heartbroken. The end. Her story had more to it, but she had slowly discovered that it was no more heavy.

“Again, I’m sorry for the outburst-”

“Don’t be.”

Her corners of her mouth turned up.

“She told me I drove her mad with my silences. She got frustrated and screamed like you. Banged around. Said she had to make up for it.”

Her smile faded, but she waited.

“At first we laughed it of, made love and that would be the end of it. But eventually, she stopped trying. To fill the silences.”

His hands were now fists at his knees. The light shone through his beard. The hair was golden, auburn, brown, and not thick enough to hide his jumping pulse. She wanted to touch him, but didn’t. It was petulant.

“Then, she was quieter than I was. Even when I found out, she was quiet. No excuse. No apology. Just a shrug, then silence. If I’d known it was so horrifying,  I would’ve tried-”

He trembled beside her, then he was weeping. It was so sudden and intense she stared for a bit. His face was a grimace, his bottom lip trembling. His sobs were desperate, sloppy. His pain was completely on the surface. She touched him, finally, two fingers on his cheek. Questioning. The heat of his tears made her nipples harden.

He leaned into her and wrapped his arms around her waist. He buried his head in her breast and she was in it now. Her sternum vibrated with his pain. He squeezed hard, gasped into her neck. His beard scratched at her saltsore skin. She had been angry before. He had made her feel like an echo. But there was more to him than what she thought. Her own tears soon wet his hair. She didn’t weep, though. She didn’t dare take that from him.

She didn’t know how long they sat that way. His grip on her did not loosen. The front of her blouse stuck to her breasts with tears, saliva and his condensed breath but she was still. Even if he just shared his pain with her, it was something, and she would cherish it.

His sobs quieted to an occasional hiccup, but he did not raise his head. She scratched the short hairs at the back of his neck, took in the scent of his hair. Her body must’ve reacted because he finally looked at her. His brown eyes were luminous with feeling. After a year of inscrutability, it made her gasp.

He took her in his arms, kissed her temple.

“I didn’t quite know how or why I did it. Just two months ago she stood in the same place you did. She loves me, she said. Misses me. I cried, hard, for her. Many nights, but not in a while. It’s like she knew.”

She stiffened again, but he rubbed her back.

“She told me what I fantasized about – that she had made a huge mistake, that he wasn’t what she thought he was. That maybe my silences weren’t that bad after all-” he wheezed. She supposed it was meant to be a snort. “-and that she wanted me to come home.”

His hand moved slowly up her spine to squeeze the back of her neck.

“As I looked at her, I finally figured out how she was different. Physically, she hadn’t changed. Not really. Same hair, same skin, same scent. But she was … uh, smaller. She no longer took up all the air in the room.”

He was looking out the window into the dark. “She knew, then. I didn’t have to say a word. Despite all her complaints about my illegibility, she knew me well enough.” His eyes were those of a man waking from a bad dream. He turned back to her.

“You. You called me a goddamn asshole.”

Her cheeks tingled. “You … saw me spinning out and didn’t react. Your face was illegible. Illegible, ha! I was pissed. I’m sorry.”

“I, uh…” a smiled played on his lips. She raised an eyebrow. “I’m sorry. I was stone-faced because I wanted to smile, but I knew if I did, you might kill me.”

“Smile?” She tucked his damp hair behind his ear. “Why?”

He let her go, reluctantly enough to make her sigh. She was quickly getting used to his touch. He rummaged in his desk, pulling at drawers that creaked.

“Jesus, why do you have that old thing?” She walked over and traced the scratched surface.

“It’s my lucky desk. Been with me all my life, I’m never getting rid of it.”

There was a box of various awards in the corner. “Ooh. Shiny things.” He walked into the dark alcove of his bedroom, muttering to himself.

She rummaged. His name, then “Editor of the Year” etched into  a glass block. Parchment. Metal. She picked up a diploma. Cornell University. Master’s in Journalism. She blew the dust off.“Why haven’t you hung this up in your office? Lord knows it cost enough.” There was no response.

There was a black and white photo at the bottom of the box, dustiest of all. A woman and a man kissing in bed. The Eiffel Tower twinkled in the distance, perfectly centered. It was a postcard.

She hesitated, then picked it up and wiped the dust off. He was young and beautiful, his long lean body naked above the waist. There were no lines at the corners of his closed eyes, no gray in the temples. There was a smile on the woman’s mouth. trail.content:
My first ever semi-fan fic, Editor!Hardy AU

Rating: Mature, for deep angst and sexual content

Wordcount: 6800

Warnings: mentions of abuse, shades of dubcon (but it’s very consensual)

I was part of other fandoms as a teenager, and been disenchanted, so I didn’t do it in adulthood. In my 20′s, I was one of those bitches who barely watched television, didn’t read comic books or stan actors/actresses, and only watched sometimes irritating, ridiculous indie films for the “brilliant photography”. Artsy Hipster trash.

I wrote for another popular blog - OC erotica - but I was miserable and uninspired. I was beyond writing just hanky-panky. I wanted to write more than porn, but at the time, I felt it was all I was good at. I didn’t feel I had the focus and the creativity to breathe life into a character and give them a compelling story. I subscribed to Netflix out of boredom. I adored Olivia Colman. I avoided Broadchurch for months because I don’t like police procedurals (ha! joke’s on me) but I couldn’t resist more Olivia. Enter Hardy. I was bested. I wrote this, left it alone in shame since I DON’T DO FAN FICTION WTF EWW IT’S SO EMBARRASSING UGH -

[I’m really putting myself out there. Please forgive my blindness.]

But I had to come back to it a few months later. I had to finish it. For years and years, all this *waving at the beautiful madness* went over my head. Then, I saw David. Oop! It had to happen sometime. Here I am.

And here it is.

Her heart hammered in her ears.

She yelled. She didn’t mean to yell. It was his eyes, so extraordinarily lovely - the very heart of autumn - were impassive, even as she spilled over in his shitty cabinet of a kitchen, trembling and hyperventilating with emotion. He remained hunched over, silent.

She flexed her hand. Her wrist was numb. She banged it on his counter, making his cups tinkle. She cursed loud enough to make his neighbors stare as she ran back to her car.

The echo of what she said filled her with an exhilarating dread. He knew now. She laid everything bare. In her passion she hadn’t only spoken her feelings for him, but made no secret of the way she felt about the way he lived his life.

Drama made her ill. She shivered, although sweat beaded her brow. She licked her lip and tasted salt. She couldn’t drive like this. She grabbed her bag on the passenger seat, and for some reason, the act finally broke her.

Her breathless, strangled groans strengthened quickly to howls. She squeezed her bag in her hands, wrung the empty flaccid thing. Her tears were plentiful and fast, and soon the leather was streaked with saltwater. She looked back at the empty passenger seat and her body stiffened. She couldn’t do it a second longer. Wait. Endure.

She opened the door to run.

“Oof!” She nearly knocked him over.

She wiped her eyes violently. “What are you doing?!” She slammed the door and started down the entrance of his courtyard. The sodium lights made his brown hair flash auburn.

“Stop.” She kept walking. Her cheeks stung. “You can’t go anywhere in that condition. Come inside. I’ll make you a cup of tea.” 

She stopped walking, but didn’t turn around.

“Come on,” he said. She heard the gravel under his heels, the slight hitch a back injury has caused.

She looked down at her waterlogged bag, then at the road. She followed him back to his cottage. He closed the door behind her, his delicate hands overly precious on the deadlock. She had wanted, and wondered at his hands.

Now he knew.

He walked to the kitchen, ducking his head on the glass fixture that hung too low. It swung softly as he made her favorite. He had made it many times - it was a thoughtless exercise. She ached, but still drank in his silence. The vertical lines between his eyes were deep. His hands were steady, pouring and stirring. The thought of his pity, of a kindness rendered to a friend in pain, made her mouth fill with saliva. She hiccuped.

He set the cup down in front of her. “Drink.” He adjusted his worn tie. His jaw clenched, but his eyes were soft. She took the cup in her hand, warm ceramic, rounded and comfortable. There was chip on the lip. She rubbed her bottom lip against it.

“My neighbor. He said you were crying in your car.”

She swallowed too deeply, and hissed as it burned down her throat.

“Really loudly.” His eyes made her hand tremble. She put the cup down. Rolled her sore eyes.

“I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to cause a disturbance.” She meant it. Now that she was empty of passion, her outburst seemed ridiculous. She stood up. “Thank you. I…um…think I’m okay to drive now.” She took quick strides to the door. “I’m sorry for everything I said it was ridiculous display I’ve been under a lot of stress lately please forget I ever did it-” Her words tumbled together. She hit the door running, nearly tore the knob off.

She stopped cold, turned her head to look at him. He stood by his table, lips parted, with expectant eyes. She was punch drunk.

“Come inside.” He pointed to his sofa. “Please.”

He was silent for a full minute, looking down at his tented fingers. She looked at his hands too, empty, sifting the light. She waited. She could exist there forever, in that silence. It crackled.

“Trouble,” he said.

“We met at an awkward time.”

“I did. You did, for a while.”

“I’m sorry.”

“Don’t be.”

Her corners of her mouth turned up.

“She told me I drove her mad with my silences. She got frustrated and screamed like you. Banged around. Said she had to make up for it.”

Her smile faded, but she waited.

“At first we laughed it of, made love and that would be the end of it. But eventually, she stopped trying. To fill the silences.”

“Jesus, why do you have that old thing?” She walked over and traced the scratched surface.

“It’s my lucky desk. Been with me all my life, I’m never getting rid of it.”

She ached, but still drank in his silence. The vertical lines between his eyes were deep. His hands were steady, pouring and stirring. The thought of his pity, of a kindness rendered to a friend in pain, made her mouth fill with saliva. She hiccuped.

He set the cup down in front of her. “Drink.” He adjusted his worn tie. His jaw clenched, but his eyes were soft. She took the cup in her hand, warm ceramic, rounded and comfortable. There was chip on the lip. She rubbed her bottom lip against it.

“My neighbor. He said you were crying in your car.”

She swallowed too deeply, and hissed as it burned down her throat.

“Really loudly.” His eyes made her hand tremble. She put the cup down. Rolled her sore eyes.

“I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to cause a disturbance.” She meant it. Now that she was empty of passion, her outburst seemed ridiculous. She stood up. “Thank you. I…um…think I’m okay to drive now.” She took quick strides to the door. “I’m sorry for everything I said it was ridiculous display I’ve been under a lot of stress lately please forget I ever did it-” Her words tumbled together. She hit the door running, nearly tore the knob off.

“I don’t want to forget.” It was barely louder than breath.

She stopped cold, turned her head to look at him. He stood by his table, lips parted, with expectant eyes. She was punch drunk.

“Come inside.” He pointed to his sofa. “Please.”
